ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of pre-recorded lectures and synchronous discussion/exercises
Prerecorded lectures, virtual seminars
Recorded Asynchronous Lectures paired with in person lecture and in person lab.
none
The course was a combination of virtual discussion and recorded lecture.
We also had asynchronous lectures, and virtual lab sessions weekly.

Learning was a combination of pre-recorded lectures where content was explained and virtual lab classes where we did class activities, went over answers to assigned homework, and sight read passages of Latin together (sometimes as a full class, and other times being put into break out rooms).

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a good understanding of Latin grammar (lots of morphology). I could translate some basic texts by the end of the course.
I learned the basics of Latin grammar in a very effective manner.
I developed an understanding of the basic syntax of of Latin and the ability to translate it.
base of Latin language understanding with regard to grammar and vocabulary
Basic Latin grammar & vocabulary

The course both provided me with a strong ability to parse latin sentences, to read simple latin sentences, and to understand latin in academic contexts nuanced by strong progressive/decolonial teaching.

In a nutshell, I learned the basic elements of Latin grammar. I learned how to identify and "parse" different parts of a sentence and translate them into English, and was also exposed to training in translating from English to Latin. I gained skills in talking through and explaining elements of Latin grammar in addition to showing written understanding of material.
On a broader spectrum, this course taught me so much about language more generally, and has influenced how I think about other languages. It has also influenced other aspects of my studies, particularly Music, as I often sing in Latin. While it was normal even before taking this class to find a translation of the piece I would be singing, now I have the tools and training to at least work out a rough translation myself. This has really enriched my experiences as a musician.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: This course did cover a fairly substantial amount of material. It was fast-paced, and if you're a Classics major, I'm sure it's helpful for your knowledge of Latin.

Weaknesses: This course was somewhat disappointing in how formulaic and bland each in-person section was. We usually went over the homework and then did grammar exercises. However, most of the time it was one person working through something while the rest of the class sat back and watched them struggle through it. Perhaps it was the Zoom environment, but it seemed like we could have spent our time much better, working on something more challenging and engaging. Most of the time I left class feeling like I hadn't learned anything the textbook hadn't told me.
It's very well-structured and systematic. No weaknesses at all.

The course was well organized but relished very heavily on asynchronous lessons too much. The synchronous zoom session spent too much time covering and reviewing previous material and quizzing students on their knowledge of the asynchronous sessions.
This course was an excellent intro to Latin!
This course was usually very approachable but intermittently very challenging due to occasional oral exams. I would suggest that the level of rigor be more equally distributed.

Strength: Pre-recorded lectures meant that I could go back and re-watch explanations if I didn't understand them right away, or re-watch them later as review for tests and exams. However...
Weakness: Pre-recorded lectures are quite frankly just not very engaging as a medium in general, and I don't think there's really anything that can be done to make it more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The asynchronous lectures were helpful insofar as it meant less time in class. They covered material succinctly and made it easy to review. Otherwise, I can't blame Zoom for the problems this class had.
The prerecorded mini-lectures were absolutely effective. So were the virtual seminars, where we corrected our exercises and could ask questions based on the material of the mini-lectures.

Overall the idea of some sessions being asynchronous was a very helpful option. Internet is sometimes unreliable and it was good to have some flexibility in scheduling for such a time demanding course. Going forward it would have been nice to have the ability to for the instructor to have a virtual chalk board of sorts. It would make lessons and discussions much easier to conceptualize with this form of visual aid.

The instructor did a very good job of utilizing the time that we had live (virtually). It ran pretty much the way I would imagine an in-person course would, with people being called upon to answer questions and working in small groups, sight-reading passages, etc.
The Friday labs could have been improved. I felt that I never really knew what exactly to expect from those sessions (how to prepare adequately).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Don't take this class unless you have to. If you're curious but not serious about Latin, just read it in translation.
Absolutely! It's a great way of being introduced to Latin.
Yes, but I would emphasize the courses heavy workload. Combined with other courses, this class can become a beast often requiring the time of two others.
Yes! A very well-done intro to Latin.
Definitely. This course was both a strong introductory language  course with compassionate teaching.
I certainly would! Latin is such a useful language because of its historical significance, continued use in some forms of worship, and its influence on so many other languages.

extras.title:
LATN 110 01
        The Elements of Latin Grammar
